description: nova quota-update should either reject tenant_ids which don't match a valid uuid or translate tenant names to tenant ids
title: novaclient quota-update should handle tenant names

comments.content: nova quota-update should either reject tenant_ids which don't match a valid uuid or translate tenant names to tenant ids
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~cyeoh-0

comments.content:
I'm not seeing this behavior.

Currently using upstream with devstack. The tenant name in the following example is 'admin'.

stack@mjturek-dev:~$ nova quota-update admin --cores 128
stack@mjturek-dev:~$ nova quota-show --tenant admin
+-----------------------------+-------+
| Quota                       | Limit |
+-----------------------------+-------+
| instances                   | 10    |
| cores                       | 128   |
| ram                         | 51200 |
| floating_ips                | 10    |
| fixed_ips                   | -1    |
| metadata_items              | 128   |
| injected_files              | 5     |
| injected_file_content_bytes | 10240 |
| injected_file_path_bytes    | 255   |
| key_pairs                   | 100   |
| security_groups             | 10    |
| security_group_rules        | 20    |
| server_groups               | 10    |
| server_group_members        | 10    |
+-----------------------------+-------+
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mjturek

comments.content:
After further investigation, I found the behavior I'm seeing to be due to a different bug.

the command does not validate against keystone to ensure that the tenant-id is an existant one. So in the example above, quota-update is treating 'admin' as the UUID rather than resolving it to a UUID.

So, the bug is still confirmed.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mjturek

comments.content:
I don't think this is a bug, but rather a feature request. novaclient doesn't say that it will accept tenant names - only tenant IDs:

    $ nova help quota-show
    usage: nova quota-show [--tenant <tenant-id>] [--user <user-id>]
    
    List the quotas for a tenant/user.
    
    Optional arguments:
      --tenant <tenant-id>  ID of tenant to list the quotas for.
      --user <user-id>      ID of user to list the quotas for.

This sounds like a feature request. This functionality is available in openstackclient and could be "backported", though I think development of "novaclient" has all but stopped at this point. Making as "invalid" until someone disagrees with this opinion :)
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~stephenfinucane

comments.content:
I think the bug is valid, just badly titled. 
The point in the description is probably the more important one - "nova quota-update should either reject tenant_ids which don't match a valid uuid".

So at the moment you can update the quota of a tenant that doesn't exist. So if there's an error when the user types in the tenant id, and he types in a tenant-id that doesn't exist, the command runs ok, and the user is none the wiser that the intended tenant has not been updated. 

You can also do a nova quota-show on a tenant-id that doesn't exist and get returned the default quota. Again you would expect to get a "tenant not found" or similar error, not something that looks like a successful completion of an invalid request.
